questions.text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of an itchy rash on her left nipple. The rash began as small vesicles on the nipple and spread to the areola. It has become a painful ulcer with a yellow, watery discharge that is occasionally blood-tinged. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled salbutamol. Her younger sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer a year ago. Examination shows a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire left nipple-areolar complex. There are no breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Paget’s disease of the nipple
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paget’s disease of the nipple Paget disease of the breast is a ductal carcinoma that infiltrates the nipple-areola complex causing an erythematous, scaly or vesicular rash accompanied by pruritus, burning, and nipple retraction . The rash eventually ulcerates and causes blood-tinged nipple discharge.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) would have a rapidly progressive clinical course, and involvement of the nipple-areola complex in IBC can result in itching and ulceration of the nipple and bloody nipple discharge . However, over a third of the breast will be erythematous, tender, indurated, and oedematous with a “peau d'orange” appearance . Palpable axillary lymph nodes are present in > 75% of cases during the clinical presentation. Option: B. Mastitis may be accompanied by fissuring of the nipple , and periductal mastitis can result in serous, serosanguinous, or purulent discharge . However, mastitis occurs typically among breastfeeding patients with an erythematous, tender, and swollen breast , and systemic symptoms such as fever would be present. Blood-tinged nipple discharge is usually not seen. Option: C. A breast abscess typically presents as a tender, palpable, fluctuant lump within the breast with erythema of the overlying skin and systemic symptoms such as fever .

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, presents with a left breast that has become larger, hot, and itchy over the past 2 months. She felt a small lump in her left breast 1 year ago but did not seek medical attention at that time. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years. Examination shows large dense breasts with widespread erythema, oedematous skin plaques over a breast mass in the left breast, tenderness, and left-sided axillary lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inflammatory breast cancer This patient has characteristic findings of inflammatory breast cancer, including breast tenderness, erythematous and oedematous skin plaques overlying a breast mass, and axillary lymphadenopathy. Several features further support this diagnosis, such as the patient's age, the history of a breast mass that the patient already noticed 1 year ago, and the positive family history of breast cancer.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The patient's age and family history of breast cancer concerns a breast malignancy such as Paget's disease of the breast . It may present with erythema, itching, and possibly a palpable breast mass, as seen in this patient. However, these findings are typically limited to the nipple and areola and do not involve the whole breast. Option: B. Mastitis is characterised by tenderness, warmth, erythema, and oedema of the affected breast and nipples, as well as reactive lymphadenopathy. All of these findings are seen in this patient. However, mastitis typically develops in breastfeeding women , most frequently within a month postpartum, making this diagnosis unlikely in this postmenopausal woman. Option: C. Breast abscess may present with tenderness, warmth, erythema, and oedema of the affected breast, as seen in this patient. However, a breast examination would typically reveal a new, fluctuant mass rather than the persistent breast lump found in this patient, which has already been present for a year. Moreover, a breast abscess is usually a complication of mastitis, making it unlikely in this postmenopausal woman without a recent history of lactation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman came to the physician because she had palpated a mass in her right breast during a self-examination a week ago. Menarche was at the age of 14, and her last menstrual period was at the age of 51. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a non-tender, firm, hard mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Mammography shows large, dense breasts, with a 1.7 cm mass in the right upper outer quadrant. The patient undergoes right upper outer quadrant lumpectomy with subsequent sentinel node biopsy, which reveals moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma and micro-metastasis to one axillary lymph node. There is no evidence of extra-nodal metastasis. The tumor tests positive for oestrogen and progesterone receptors and does not show human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) over-expression. Which of the following factors greatly affects this patient's prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nodal status The status of axillary lymph nodes in patients with breast cancer is considered the most important prognostic factor for disease outcome. If axillary lymph nodes have been involved, metastatic spread to other organs is likely, and survival rates are lower. Detection of metastases in the lymph nodes is also associated with higher cancer recurrence rates .

Highyeild:

Prognosis of breast cancer. Disease factors Patient factors ● Size of tumour ● Stage of disease ● Axillary lymph node involvement ● Grade of tumour ● Histopathological variant (metaplastic carcinoma is aggressive): ○ Her2/neu positive and triple negative ○ Presence of lymphovascular invasion ○ Extensive DCIS component ○ High Ki-67 index ● Younger age ● Premenopausal women ● BRCA-associated tumour ● Family history of breast cancer ● Prior history of breast cancer ● Obesity, sedentary lifestyle ● Failure to complete intended treatment DCIS, ductal carcinoma in situ. "The Nottingham prognostic index (NPI) is used to determine prognosis following surgery. It is calculated using tumour size (S), number of involved lymph nodes (N) and tumour grade (G). NPI = (0.2 x S) + N + G. Patients are grouped into four categories according to the NPI score: I (excellent) ≤2.4; II (good) >2.4 but ≤3.4; III (moderate) >3.4 but $5.4; and IV (poor) >5.4.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. This patient's findings of moderately differentiated tumor cells are consistent with an intermediate histologic tumor grade . While higher histologic grades negatively affect the prognosis in breast cancer patients , nodal status is a more important factor. Option: C. A positive HER2 receptor status in breast cancer patients is associated with aggressive tumor growth, high-grade tumors, and a poor prognosis , especially if the oestrogen and progesterone hormone receptor status is also negative. Since this patient's HER2 receptor status is negative, it does not have a negative impact on this patient's prognosis. Regardless, another factor is even more important. Option: D. While a positive receptor status is a risk factor for increased cancer growth, a negative receptor status is associated with a poorer prognosis since it means targeted hormone therapy cannot be given. However, the hormone receptor status is not the most important prognostic factor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no other significant medical history presented to the Surgery OPD complaining of a lump in her right breast. There is no Family History of Carcinoma in the patient. Which of the following about examination in this patient is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual inspection & Axillary lymph nodes examination of the patient is done in the upright sitting position, whereas Palpation of the breast is done with the patient lying supine.

options.label: B
options.text: Paget disease originates on the nipple and secondarily involves the areola

options.label: C
options.text: Any Involvement of the nipple and areola complex is a clear-cut sign of Carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: Fibroadenomas, cysts, and carcinomas all can be firm on Palpation

questions.correct_answer: C. Any Involvement of the nipple and areola complex is a clear-cut sign of Carcinoma.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Any Involvement of the nipple and areola complex is a clear-cut sign of Carcinoma. Physical Examination of the breast includes Visual inspection & Palpation of the breast and Axillary lymph nodes. The examination begins with the patient in an upright sitting position.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. The breasts are visually inspected for obvious masses, asymmetries, and skin changes. The examiner supports the patient’s arm and palpates each axilla from a posterior approach to detect the presence of enlarged axillary lymph nodes. The supraclavicular and infraclavicular spaces are similarly palpated for enlarged nodes. Palpation of the breast is always done with the patient lying supine on a solid examining surface, with the arm stretched above the head. Palpation of the breast while the patient is sitting often leads to inaccurate interpretation because the overlapping breast tissue may feel like a mass, or a mass may go undetected within the breast tissue. Option: B. Eczema begins on the areola , whereas Paget disease originates on the nipple and secondarily involves the areola. Option: C. Dimpling of the skin or nipple retraction is a sensitive and specific sign of underlying cancer . Still, flattening or inversion of the nipple can also be seen in subareolar duct ectasia . The finding is frequently bilateral in these cases, with a long history confirming the condition. Option: D. Fibroadenomas, cysts, and carcinomas can all be firm on Palpation. The differences are that the Fibroadenomas & cysts are well-circumscribed and movable , whereas moving a carcinoma produces a drag of adjacent tissue .

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a lump in her breast was examined and was found to have a firm mass which was not well-circumscribed. A core needle biopsy of the lesion was planned. Of the following statements, which is TRUE regarding this decision?

options.label: A
options.text: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA), which is a common tool in the diagnosis of breast masses, & is generally the first choice of investigation

options.label: B
options.text: Core needle biopsy is the method of choice to sample breast lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Excisional biopsy for definitive diagnosis is needed in every case

options.label: D
options.text: FNAC, being an invasive procedure, can be helpful in molecular studies and in knowing receptor status

questions.correct_answer: B. Core needle biopsy is the method of choice to sample breast lesions
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Core needle biopsy is the method of choice to sample breast lesions Histopathological Examination of the Breast can be done by: Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology, Core Needle Biopsy, or Excisional Biopsy. FNAC is the least invasive technique for obtaining a cellular diagnosis and is rapid . It is obtained using a 21G or 23G needle and 10-mL syringe with multiple passes through the lump with negative pressure in the syringe. The aspirate is then smeared on a slide that is air-dried or fixed. Core Needle Biopsy is the method of choice to sample breast lesions. The size of a CNB needle ranges from 8 to 14 gauge . It can be USG/MRI guided . Excisional Biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis but is only done in a few specific cases. Core Needle Biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure & is the preferred approach for diagnosing breast lesions.

options.text: Plan for Sentinel Node Biopsy during the surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate LN Excision and Histopathological Examination.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

FNAC of LN In Lymph nodes suspicious on either physical examination or imaging, FNAC is used to evaluate metastatic disease. It also helps in the initial staging of breast cancer, provides prognostic information and helps determine appropriate management strategies.

FNAC The sensitivity and specificity of FNAC for breast cancer diagnosis are approximately 90% and 95%, respectively. It is not always accurate to differentiate between invasive breast cancer and DCIS, which can result in unnecessary treatment for DCIS. False-positive results may occur in benign lesions with atypical features, such as radial scars or papillomas.

questions.correct_answer: A. Level 1 nodes are most commonly involved with the spread of cancer.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Level 1 nodes are most commonly involved with the spread of cancer. Lymph nodes located lateral to or below the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle are referred to as Level I lymph nodes , which include the axillary vein, external mammary, and scapular groups. Level II nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle, anterior to the pectoralis minor, and posterior to the pectoralis major (also called, Rotter or interpectoral nodes ). Level III nodes are located medial to the Pectoralis minor muscle, which consists of the sub-clavicular group.

The sentinel lymph node is functionally the first node in the axillary chain and, anatomically, is usually found in the external mammary group (Anterior, Pectoral), a part of LEVEL I Lymph Nodes . Option: B. Level II nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle, anterior to the pectoralis minor, and posterior to the pectoralis major (also called, Rotter or interpectoral nodes ). Option: C . Level III nodes are located medial to Pectoralis minor muscle. Option: D . Internal Mammary Lymph Nodes drain the medial aspect of the breast.
